semantic_title: Place of Occurrence Code Guidelines and Usage Rules
section_path: Chapter 20: External Causes of Morbidity > b. Place of Occurrence Guideline

content.full_text: Codes from category Y92, Place of occurrence of the external cause, are secondary codes for use after other external cause codes to identify the location of the patient at the time of injury or other condition. Generally, a place of occurrence code is assigned only once, at the initial encounter for treatment. However, in the rare instance that a new injury occurs during hospitalization, an additional place of occurrence code may be assigned. No 7th characters are used for Y92. Do not use place of occurrence code Y92.9 if the place is not stated or is not applicable. (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L55)
content.summary: Y92 place of occurrence codes are secondary codes used once at initial encounter, with exceptions for new injuries during hospitalization, and do not use 7th characters (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L55)
key_concepts: Y92 codes are secondary codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
Used after other external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
Identify location at time of injury (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53)
Generally assigned only once at initial encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)
Exception for new injuries during hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
No 7th characters used (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
Don't use Y92.9 if place not stated (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Y92 codes are secondary codes used after other external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
detailed_rules.explanation: Place of occurrence codes provide additional information about location and must be sequenced after the primary external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
detailed_rules.applies_to: All Y92 place of occurrence codes

detailed_rules.rule_text: Place of occurrence codes generally assigned only once at initial encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)
detailed_rules.explanation: Unlike other codes that may be repeated at subsequent encounters, place of occurrence is typically coded only at the first encounter for treatment (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Additional place of occurrence code may be assigned for new injury during hospitalization (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
detailed_rules.explanation: In rare instances when a patient sustains a new injury while hospitalized, an additional place of occurrence code may be assigned for the new injury (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Y92 codes do not use 7th characters (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
detailed_rules.explanation: Unlike most external cause codes, place of occurrence codes do not require 7th character extensions (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Do not use Y92.9 if place is not stated or not applicable (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)
detailed_rules.explanation: The unspecified place of occurrence code should not be used when the place is unknown or not applicable to the situation (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Assign primary external cause codes first
Step 2: Determine the location where injury occurred
Step 3: Assign appropriate Y92 place of occurrence code
Step 4: Verify this is initial encounter (or new injury during hospitalization)
Step 5: Confirm no 7th character is needed

code_ranges.description: Place of occurrence of the external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52)
usage_rules: Use after other external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
Generally assign only once at initial encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)

specific_codes.description: Unspecified place of occurrence (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)
specific_codes.context: Do not use if place not stated or not applicable

breakdown.usage_restriction: Avoid when place unknown or not applicable (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient falls at home and fractures wrist, seen in ED initially, then follow-up visits
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient fell down stairs at home, sustained wrist fracture, treated in ED
step_by_step: Step 1: Code wrist fracture as primary diagnosis
Step 2: Code fall down stairs as external cause
Step 3: Code Y92.009 (home) as place of occurrence at initial encounter only
Step 4: Do not repeat Y92 code at subsequent encounters

correct_coding.primary_code: Wrist fracture code with 7th character A
secondary_codes: Fall external cause code with 7th character A
correct_coding.sequencing: Fracture, external cause, place of occurrence
correct_coding.rationale: Place of occurrence coded only once at initial encounter, not repeated at subsequent visits (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)

codes: Repeating place of occurrence at follow-up visits
incorrect_coding.rationale: Place of occurrence generally coded only once
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Repeating Y92 codes at subsequent encounters

warnings: Don't use Y92.9 when place not stated (Evidence: pg no: 89, L55)
Don't repeat Y92 codes at subsequent encounters unless new injury (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L55)
best_practices: Code place of occurrence only at initial encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)
Sequence after other external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L52-L53)
common_mistakes: Using Y92 codes at every encounter (Evidence: pg no: 89, L53-L54)
Adding 7th characters to Y92 codes (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
tips: Y92 codes don't need 7th characters (Evidence: pg no: 89, L54-L55)
implementation_notes: Exception exists for new injuries during hospitalization
clinical_context: Location information valuable for injury prevention research
